title: How Many Times Is Love in the Bible?

steps.title: Love is mentioned 310 times in the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible.
steps.content: Love is mentioned 310 times in the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. Yup, you heard that right—the word “love” is a frequent flier in both the Old and New Testaments. The same is the case for the New King James Version (NKJV), a slightly updated version of the original KJV that features the word “love” a total of 361 times. Here’s a look at where some other popular translations stack up: [1] X Research source New Living Translation (NLT): 645 times New International Version (NIV): 574 times English Standard Version (ESV): 551 times North American Standard Bible 2020 (NASB20): 348 times

steps.title: The word "Lord" is mentioned 7,888 times in the KJV.
steps.content: The word "Lord" is mentioned 7,888 times in the KJV. When it comes to Bible verses, no word is referenced more than "Lord," or the honorific that people use to address or refer to God. The New King James Version (NKJV) includes the word slightly less than the KJV, featuring it only 7,825 times. [2] X Research source NLT: 7,443 times NIV: 7,590 times ESV: 7,821 times NASB20: 7,790 times Example verse: “And the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.” Genesis 2:7

steps.title: The word "God" is used 4,459 times in the KJV Bible.
steps.content: The word "God" is used 4,459 times in the KJV Bible. Christianity revolves around faith in God, so it’s only natural that this very word would be one of the most common ones found in the Bible. [3] X Research source NLT: 4,576 times NIV: 4,047 times ESV: 4,378 times NASB20: 4,374 times Example verse: “Behold, God will not cast away a perfect man, neither will he help the evil doers.” Job 8:20

steps.title: The word "man" is featured 2,640 times in the KJV Bible.
steps.content: The word "man" is featured 2,640 times in the KJV Bible. The word “man” is used quite a lot in the Bible, especially by Jesus, who uses the term “Son of Man” to refer to Himself in the third person. [4] X Research source In total, the KJV features the word 2,640 times, while the NKJV includes it 2,107 times. [5] X Research source NLT: 1,271 times NIV: 1,304 times ESV: 2,043 times NASB20: 1,452 times Example verse: “And said, Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of Man standing on the right hand of God.” Acts 7:56

steps.title: The word "Israel" is used 2,568 times in the KJV Bible.
steps.content: The word "Israel" is used 2,568 times in the KJV Bible. Starting in the Old Testament, God heralds the Jewish community of Israel as His “chosen people”—for instance, in Deuteronomy 7:6, He says “For thou art a holy people unto the Lord thy God: the Lord thy God hath chosen thee to be a special people unto Himself, above all people that are upon the face of the earth.” [6] X Research source So, it makes sense that Israel is mentioned 2,568 times in the KJV and 2,570 times in the NKJV. [7] X Research source NLT: 2,292 times NIV: 1,798 times ESV: 2,569 times NASB20: 2,571 times Example verse: “He shall cause them that come of Jacob to take root: Israel shall blossom and bud, and fill the face of the world with fruit.” Isaiah 27:6

steps.title: The word "people" is used 2,141 times in the KJV Bible.
steps.content: The word "people" is used 2,141 times in the KJV Bible. Given the sheer number of prophecies and battles that take place in the Bible, it’s no surprise that the word “people” pops up pretty frequently. While the KJV features this word 2,141 times, the NKJV features it slightly less—only 2,139 times. [8] X Research source NLT: 3,558 times NIV: 2,702 times ESV: 2,856 times NASB20: 2,422 times Example verse: “Wherefore Jesus also, that he might sanctify the people with His own blood, suffered without the gate.” Hebrews 13:12

steps.title: Agape (aga-pay): unconditional love
steps.content: Agape (aga-pay): unconditional love The Greek word "agape" is one of the best ways out there to describe how the God of Christianity loves His followers. It’s a type of love that has no strings attached—it’s freely offered even if the recipient chooses not to accept it. It’s also commonly associated with the concept of forgiveness, and absolving someone regardless of what they’ve said or done. [9] X Research source Example in the Bible: “But commendeth His love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.” Romans 5:8

steps.title: Hesed (kheh-sed): undeserved love
steps.content: Hesed (kheh-sed): undeserved love Similar to agape, "hesed" (חֶסֶד) refers to a dedicated, steadfast love that God feels for mankind. It’s also represented in some of the ways that people love each other, like a parent caring diligently and patiently for their child. In the Hebrew translation of the Bible, hesed is often used to represent an active form of love, like Ruth’s decision to stay with her mother-in-law Naomi after Naomi’s sons and husband had passed away. [10] X Research source Example in the Bible: “How excellent is thy lovingkindness, O God! Therefore the children of men put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.” Psalm: 36:7

steps.title: Philia (fih-lee-uh): affectionate, platonic love
steps.content: Philia (fih-lee-uh): affectionate, platonic love "Philia" is another Greek word for love—but instead of describing God’s love for mankind, it illustrates the love that people have for their friends and fellow human beings. [11] X Research source Philia was an important concept in Jesus’s ministry as he stressed the importance of loving one another (and even loving one’s enemy). [12] X Research source Example in the Bible: “Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love; in honour preferring one another.” Romans 12:10

steps.title: Ahav (ah-HAV): a broad type of love
steps.content: Ahav (ah-HAV): a broad type of love In Hebrew, "ahav" (אהב) means “to love,” while ahavah (אהבה) is simply the noun “love.” Both of these terms mention love in a very general sense and are used in a variety of Biblical scenarios, like describing David and Jonathan’s relationship in the Old Testament (2 Samuel 1:26). [13] X Research source Example in the Bible: “And thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength: this is the first commandment.” Mark 12:30

steps.title: Luke 6:35
steps.content: Luke 6:35 “But love ye your enemies, and do good, and lend, hoping for nothing again; and your reward shall be great, and ye shall be the children of the Highest: for he is kind unto the unthankful and to the evil.”

steps.title: 1 Corinthians 13:4-8
steps.content: 1 Corinthians 13:4-8 “Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It does not dishonor others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Love never fails. But where there are prophecies, they will cease; where there are tongues, they will be stilled; where there is knowledge, it will pass away.” (NIV)

steps.title: 1 John 4:16-18
steps.content: 1 John 4:16-18 “And we have known and believed the love that God hath to us. God is love; and he that dwelleth in love dwelleth in God, and God in him. Herein is our love made perfect, that we may have boldness in the day of judgment: because as he is, so are we in this world. There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear: because fear hath torment. He that feareth is not made perfect in love.”

steps.title: Colossians 3:14
steps.content: Colossians 3:14 “Above all, clothe yourselves with love, which binds us all together in perfect harmony.” (NLT)

steps.title: Proverbs 17:17
steps.content: Proverbs 17:17 “A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.”

steps.title: John 3:16
steps.content: John 3:16 “For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.”
